title: Academic Argumentation Structures
description: Mastering complex grammatical patterns for scholarly discourse

sections.title: Concessive Structures
sections.explanation: Advanced concessive constructions acknowledge opposing arguments while maintaining your position.

patterns.pattern: Granting/Granted that..., it remains the case that...
patterns.example: Granted that the evidence is incomplete, it remains the case that a clear pattern emerges.
patterns.function: Acknowledges limitation while asserting main point

patterns.example: For all its methodological innovation, the study still fails to address causation.
Notwithstanding these reservations, the theory offers valuable insights.

patterns.pattern: Compelling as X may be, Y...
patterns.example: Compelling as this argument may be, it rests on questionable assumptions.

sections.title: Extraposition and Cleft Structures
sections.explanation: Manipulating information structure for emphasis and flow.

patterns.name: Extraposed subjects
patterns.basic: That he would make such a claim is surprising.
patterns.extraposed: It is surprising that he would make such a claim.

patterns.name: It-clefts for focus
patterns.cleft: It is the methodology that undermines the conclusions.

patterns.name: Wh-clefts (pseudo-clefts)
patterns.neutral: We need a more nuanced approach.
patterns.cleft: What we need is a more nuanced approach.
patterns.effect: Emphasizes the information in the complement

patterns.name: Reverse wh-clefts
patterns.neutral: The social context is what matters most.

sections.title: Subjunctive in Academic Writing
sections.explanation: The subjunctive mood in formal academic and legal contexts.

uses.example: The committee recommends that the proposal be revised.
uses.note: Common in academic and legal writing; 'should' alternative less formal

uses.example: Were it not for this oversight, the argument would be persuasive.
uses.note: 'If it were not' inverted for formal effect

sections.title: Parallelism and Rhetorical Balance
sections.explanation: Using parallel structures for clarity, emphasis, and persuasive effect.

techniques.name: Tricolon
techniques.example: The theory is elegant in conception, rigorous in methodology, and profound in implications.

techniques.name: Antithesis
techniques.example: What the old paradigm obscures, the new reveals.

techniques.name: Anaphora
techniques.description: Repetition at the beginning of successive clauses
techniques.example: It is not enough to document these patterns. It is not enough to theorize their origins. It is necessary to transform the conditions that produce them.

exercises.original: Although this evidence is persuasive, it does not prove causation.
exercises.answer: Compelling as this evidence may be, it does not prove causation.

exercises.instruction: Transform into an it-cleft for emphasis
exercises.original: The lack of longitudinal data weakens the study.
exercises.answer: It is the lack of longitudinal data that weakens the study.

exercises.sentence: The board insisted that the CEO _____ (resign) immediately.
